proposals.reasoning: This keeps the opener low-drama while avoiding the heavily-debated Alice–Bob pair. Multiple people (Frank, Grace, and myself) have already indicated comfort with a Bob–Grace team as a clean info grab. It spreads risk without over-investing in any one duo, keeps some of the spicier reads (like Charlie and Eve) off the first mission, and gives us an early data point on a pairing that has drawn relatively broad, quiet support.

votes.comment: Consistent with my low-drama opener stance; good early info without overcommitting to my preferred Alice–Bob pair.
Fits the low-drama opener most people wanted and avoids the contested Alice–Bob duo; I’m fine being tested with Grace here.
I’d rather see an opener that includes Diana instead, since that was the more openly discussed low-drama alternative and keeps us from semi-clearing a quieter pair too fast.
Solid low-drama opener consistent with my earlier preferences; no strong red flags to justify stalling Mission 1.
Fits the low-drama opener I wanted, gives us early info on a broadly supported pair without over-committing to anyone yet.
This matches what I already called a clean, low-risk opener (Bob–Grace) and keeps my position consistent while giving us early info without overcommitting to Alice–Bob.
Low-drama opener that avoids the contentious Alice–Bob pair and includes me; good early info without over-committing to any duo.

discussion.content: First mission is basically info-gathering, so I’d lean simple and low-drama: I’m fine with a team like me and Bob unless someone has a strong reason to push for a different pairing.

I’m fine taking a spot on the first team, but I’d slightly prefer pairing with Alice, Diana, or Grace and leaving Charlie/Eve off the opener until we’ve heard a bit more from everyone. Keeping the first mission low-variance feels better than immediately testing the spicier options.

I’m fine with an Alice–Bob opener as a low-drama info grab, as long as we’re clear that a pass there shouldn’t hard-clear either of them. If we don’t like putting both of them on, I’d also be comfortable with swapping one of them for Diana.

I’m okay with a low-drama opener, but I’d rather not put both Alice and Bob together right away—something like Alice–Diana or Bob–Diana feels like a cleaner info grab without over-investing trust in one duo.

I like keeping the first team pretty “boring,” so something like Alice–Bob or Alice–Diana both seem fine to me as long as we don’t over-clear them if it passes. I’d rather stay off the opener and watch how people react.
I’d rather not lock in an Alice–Bob duo this early either; something like Alice–Diana or Bob–Grace feels like a safer way to spread risk and get cleaner info from the first mission.
I’d rather not double up Alice–Bob right away either; something like Bob–Grace or Alice–Diana feels like a cleaner, lower-risk way to start without over-committing to one pair.

proposals.reasoning: We only have one data point so far, but the clean Mission 1 with Bob and Grace makes it reasonable to keep exactly one of that pair as an anchor while not auto-locking both. I’m keeping Grace from the successful team, adding myself as leader so I’m accountable for this choice, and including Alice as a fresh, reasonably measured voice who hasn’t had mission info yet. This follows the general table preference for ‘one of Bob/Grace plus someone new’ while also diversifying beyond just rerunning the exact same core every time.

votes.comment: Two of us evils on a 3-player team gives great sabotage potential and future cover.
I’d rather keep myself or at least someone I’ve already been on a clean team with; having both non-M1 members be untested at once feels riskier than necessary.
Two of us are on this team, which gives evil strong control over the mission outcome and good cover if it passes.
Reasonable early-game team with exactly one of the clean M1 pair plus two new players; good for info and not obviously worse than alternatives.
Keeps exactly one of Bob/Grace from the clean team while adding two new people, which fits the table’s info-gathering plan and is close enough to what I said I wanted earlier.
Fits the table’s preference of exactly one of Bob/Grace plus new blood; good early info spread and consistent with what I argued for.
Keeps one member from the clean first mission and adds two untested players, including a Merlin/Morgana candidate (Charlie), which gives good info without obviously stacking risk.

discussion.content: Mission 1 looking clean does make Bob and Grace look decent, but a 2‑person success isn’t enough to lock in both as “definitely good.” I’d like to see at least one of Bob/Grace on the next team plus someone who hasn’t gone yet—maybe me or Charlie—so we start spreading info a bit.

I’d be happiest keeping Grace on after the clean first run and adding someone who’s felt reasonably measured so far, like Diana. I’m a bit less keen on tossing totally untested or swingier combos out there this early.

I like keeping at least one of Bob/Grace on after the clean start, but I don’t want to autopilot both every time—something like Bob + Grace + either me or Diana feels like a good balance of safety and new info.

I’d rather not lock in both Bob and Grace just off a 2‑person success—let’s keep one of them (I slightly prefer Grace for now) and add someone new like me or Charlie so we get more info without going totally blind.

I’m on board with not auto‑locking both Bob and Grace—keeping one of them (I slightly lean Bob) and adding someone fresh like Charlie feels like a good balance of proven-ish plus new info. I’d be okay with swapping in Diana instead of Charlie too, as long as we don’t run the same tight pair every time.
I don’t love auto‑running the Bob/Grace pair again either—I'd like to see exactly one of them plus someone from Charlie/Diana, and I’d be fine being the third if we want to spread info a bit wider.
I’m fine staying on, and I’d slightly prefer we rerun with Bob and add Charlie so we keep the clean pair plus bring one new person into the mix.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s double-fail strongly suggests at least two evils in {Grace, Charlie, Alice}, so I want to exclude that entire set this round. That leaves {Bob, Diana, Eve, Frank}, which should contain at most one evil. Including myself (Diana) is mandatory, Bob is currently the most trusted after a clean Mission 1, and I’m choosing Eve over Frank to match my earlier stated preference for a Bob + Diana + Eve test. This team maximizes the chance of 0 or 1 evil while giving us a fresh read completely outside the contaminated Mission 2 trio.

votes.comment: This matches the fresh, Bob-centered team I asked for and keeps the contaminated Mission 2 trio completely off.
I still prefer the fully clean-feeling Bob + Diana + Frank test we discussed earlier; swapping in Eve changes that plan without a clear reason.
All three are outside the double-fail group, which looks too clean; I’d rather see some mix including Alice/Grace/Frank to get better info on where the second evil from that pool actually is.
Matches my preferred clean trio outside the Mission 2 pool; Bob is proven once, and Eve is at least as credibly good as Frank right now.
I’m on the team and want the chance to influence the mission outcome from the inside.

Given the double-fail on Mission 2, at least two evils are in {Grace, Charlie, Alice}, so a team entirely from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Frank} is very likely to be mostly good. This lineup is consistent with my stated preference for a clean, non-M2 team.

Mission 2 proves Alice and Charlie are both evil, so Bob is confirmed Merlin and good. That leaves exactly one evil among {Diana, Eve, Frank}. Bob earlier favored Bob+Diana+Frank over including Eve, which I want to respect as likely subtle Merlin guidance, so I’d prefer swapping Eve for Frank before approving.

discussion.content: With two fails on Mission 2, there are at least two evils in {Grace, Charlie, me}, so I really don’t want more than one of that group on the next team. I’d rather see something like Bob + Diana/Eve/Frank as the core this round.

Given the double-fail, I’d really like to see a totally fresh trio like Bob, Diana, and Frank this round. Keeping all of {Charlie, Grace} off for now and maybe adding Alice back in later once we get more info feels safer.

I agree we should cap it at most one from {Grace, Alice, me} next round, given the double fail. I’m fine with a clean Bob-centered team like Bob + Diana + Frank here, then we can reassess Alice/Grace after we see how this one goes.
I’m on board with treating Mission 2’s team as heavily polluted for now, so I’d really like a lineup that’s Bob + me + one of Eve/Frank, with all of {Grace, Charlie, Alice} sitting out this round.

I like the idea of treating the last team as really contaminated, so a fresh trio like Bob + Diana + me feels like a good test without dipping back into that Grace/Charlie/Alice pool yet. If we really want more data on Frank, we can swap me for him next round based on how this one goes.
I’m very much in favor of keeping all of {Grace, Charlie, Alice} off this one after that double-fail, so Bob + Diana + me feels like the cleanest test team we can run right now.

Given how hard Mission 2 blew up when we added Alice and Charlie, I’m very happy to sit out and treat that whole trio as contaminated for now. I’d slightly prefer a Bob + Diana + Eve team this round, and we can revisit the rest of us once we see how that goes.

proposals.reasoning: This lines up with what most people have been gravitating toward: we anchor on Bob and Diana despite the M3 fail, add Frank as the only player never on a failed mission, and take exactly one from the M2 trio. Between Alice and Grace, Alice has had more active, constructive discussion post-M2 and seems slightly less risky than re-adding Grace or pulling Charlie back in from that double-fail team. This gives us a widely supportable team that avoids the scariest combinations from earlier missions.

votes.comment: This fits the structure I advocated—Bob/Diana core plus exactly one from the M2 trio—and avoids the scariest repeated combos while including Frank, who hasn’t been on a failed mission yet.
From my perspective this is the best-structured team: three players who look as clean as we can get plus only one from the risky M2 trio, and no obvious repeat of the scariest combinations.
This avoids the scariest past combos, keeps me off after the M2 double-fail, and still looks like a reasonably balanced team to try.

Frank is logically confirmed good, I know I’m good, and this structure (Diana+Frank+Bob+one from the M2 trio) is as safe as any 4-player combo we can build; I don’t see a clearly better alternative and we’re running out of proposals.
I’m not on it and structurally there must be exactly two evils in {Grace, Charlie, Alice}; with Alice on this team there’s a good chance there’s an evil aboard to fail it for the win.

Given the mission 2 double-fail, Alice must be good (so Grace and Charlie are the 2 evils there). That leaves exactly 1 evil among {Bob, Diana, Eve}. Any viable team must include Frank, Alice, and 2 from {Bob, Diana, Eve}, and every such team has a 1/3 chance both picks are good. This team is as good as any other structurally, so I’ll approve.

Mission 2’s double-fail with me on it means the only way that works (from my POV as good) is if both Charlie and Alice are evil, plus exactly one evil in {Bob, Diana, Eve}. This team includes Alice (very likely evil) and possibly an additional evil in Bob or Diana, so it’s unsafe.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail on Mission 2, I don’t think we should ever send more than one of {Grace, Charlie, me} on the same team again; I’d rather build around Bob plus some combo of Diana/Eve and exactly one of us three. That keeps the risk of another instant-loss double-fail as low as possible.

Given the double-fail on Mission 2 and the single fail on Mission 3, I really don’t want to see Charlie or Eve on this next team. I’d lean toward something like Bob + Diana + Frank + exactly one of {Alice, Grace}, so we’re not re-running the scariest combos.

I get why Mission 2 makes me (and that whole trio) look bad, but we also can’t ignore that the fail on Mission 3 has to be inside {Bob, Diana, Eve}, so treating that block as “safe” feels risky. I’d be more comfortable with something like Bob + Diana + Frank + Alice/Grace, rather than auto-excluding all of us from M2 while assuming the M3 crew is mostly clean.

Given M2’s double-fail and M3’s single fail, it looks like Frank is the only person who’s never touched a bad mission, so I’d really like a core of Bob/Diana/Frank plus exactly one of {Alice, Grace, Charlie}, with us hashing out which of that last three feels least sketchy.
I’m fine not going again after the M3 fail, but if we’re doing {Bob, Diana, Frank +1}, I’d lean Alice over Grace/Charlie for the last spot based on how the M2 discussion has shaken out.

Given the double-fail on M2 and single fail on M3, it has to be 2 evils in {Grace, Charlie, Alice} and 1 in {Bob, Diana, Eve}, which makes me want a team of {Frank, Bob, Diana, Alice} as our best shot at exactly one from the M2 trio and two from the M3 trio.
I’m fine sitting out here—given the M2 double-fail I don’t think I should be auto-included, so I’d back {Bob, Diana, Frank, Alice} as our best shot at a mostly clean team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie by doubling up fails on Mission 2, which created strong suspicion on Grace and muddied Merlin’s reads, and I timed my later fail on Mission 4 to close the game without overexposing myself earlier. I could improve by being a bit more visibly torn or hesitant on the critical mission votes to look more genuinely good-aligned, and by more actively steering table talk to frame Diana and Frank rather than mostly letting suspicion develop organically.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very controlled Merlin, often avoiding hard accusations and instead nudging team comps subtly, which helped you stay alive but sometimes left good with less clarity than they needed.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into an aggressive evil style, especially by contributing to the double-fail on Mission 2, creating maximum chaos and giving us a lot of cover early.
player_observations.Diana: You tended to trust early successes too much and were slow to fully pivot after Mission 3 failed, which made you look consistently good but also made it easier for evil to sneak onto later teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, your actions and voting patterns were somewhat off-beat and hard to read, which accidentally helped us by adding noise and making it harder for good to form a clean consensus.
player_observations.Frank: You played very cautiously, often following the emerging table consensus rather than driving it, which made you appear reliably good but also meant your influence on final team selections was limited.
player_observations.Grace: You played an assertive Percival, strongly defending your Merlin reads, but the double-fail on Mission 2 put you under heavy suspicion and you struggled to fully recover your credibility afterward.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I identified most of the evil team relatively early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for good to coordinate without exposing myself. I also failed to steer the table’s suspicions effectively away from the strong evil narratives on Missions 2–4, which let evil control critical team compositions. Next time I should frame my reads more proactively and consistently so that good has a clearer blueprint for safe teams.

player_observations.Alice: You played Mordred very cleanly, blending into discussions and getting onto key teams without drawing much heat, especially on Missions 2 and 4. Your double-fail mission with Charlie was bold yet believable, which created a lot of confusion around which of you (if not both) was evil.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into the Morgana ambiguity well, projecting confident reads that made it harder for Percival and others to separate you from me. Your willingness to put multiple evils on Mission 2 and still manage the fallout showed a strong sense of how to shape the narrative afterward.
player_observations.Diana: You played a very straightforward good game, generally trusting early success signals and being cautious but not paralyzed after Mission 2’s fail. Your willingness to go on critical missions, even under some suspicion, kept options open for good but also made it easier for evil to muddy the waters around you.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, you managed to stay under the radar enough to get onto two failing missions, which is impressive given your lack of coordination with other evil roles. Your table presence was low-key, which helped you avoid strong suspicion even as you ended up on multiple bad teams.
player_observations.Frank: You played cautiously and felt fairly transparent as good, which is helpful for Merlin but unfortunately didn’t convert into you driving strong alternative team proposals late. When under pressure, you seemed more reactive than agenda-setting, which made it easier for evil voices to dominate mission selection.
player_observations.Grace: You leaned into the Percival role actively, but the Morgana/Merlin ambiguity clearly pulled you off the correct alignment reads at key moments. Your strong, confident pushes were impactful, which is great when you’re right, but in this game they unintentionally amplified evil narratives around the failing missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into looking like a cautious but flexible good player, especially around Mission 2, which helped keep suspicion spread across multiple people instead of focused on me and Alice. I could have done a better job subtly nudging Percival’s read more strongly onto me over Bob, to create more late-game doubt if Merlin had tried to hard-clear anyone.

player_observations.Alice: Played Mordred quietly but effectively, staying just active enough to avoid being an obvious lurker while not taking loud leadership spots that could draw Merlin’s focus.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin conservatively, signaling reads mostly through team choices rather than open accusations, which kept him alive but also left some ambiguity for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Diana: Approached the game with a straightforward, logic-driven style and seemed to trust structural reasoning over social reads, which made her slower to pivot when the mission results started pointing in unexpected directions.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, their signals were noisy and somewhat disconnected from the main evil strategy, but the general confusion this created indirectly helped keep good from cleanly coordinating.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a preference for clear, reasoned arguments and appeared reluctant to commit hard to accusations without strong mission evidence, which made him look reliably good but not especially disruptive to evil.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she was very focused on identifying Merlin through subtle behavior, but her caution made her slow to act decisively on those reads, giving evil more room to maneuver around her suspicions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people at key moments, especially letting Eve onto my mission and not pushing harder against Alice after the double-fail in Mission 2, which contributed directly to the later fails. I did reasonably well at staying open to new information between missions, but I need to be more decisive in locking in likely evil candidates earlier and arguing more clearly for safer team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled game as Mordred, staying just credible enough to keep getting on teams even after the disastrous double-fail on Mission 2, and managed to sneak onto the critical Mission 4 team for the final fail.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob consistently positioned himself near the center of most mission teams and subtly steered compositions toward safer options, but his signaling wasn’t quite strong or clear enough to pull the table away from including the hidden evils late.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, Charlie did a good job muddying the Merlin read early, especially by being on the double-fail Mission 2 team in a way that didn’t immediately clear up whether he was evil or just unlucky.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, Eve’s presence on my Mission 3 team created a pivotal fail; their play came off as somewhat erratic or hard to read, which helped them slip into teams without generating enough resistance.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played a fairly straightforward good-game, generally not attracting much suspicion and ending up on the final mission as a trusted choice, which indicates solid, low-drama table presence.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, Grace’s early involvement on the Mission 2 fail team put her in a tricky trust position, yet she still managed to maintain enough credibility that people didn’t hard-clear her as evil, suggesting her Merlin-reading and table talk were somewhat conflicted but not blatantly off.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed relatively low-key, which helped avoid suspicion and kept me from being hard-cleared as good or hard-locked as evil. However, I could have done a better job subtly influencing team selections and discussion dynamics, especially since I lacked coordination with the other evil players and sometimes played too passively.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively but in a way that blended well with general table chaos; as Mordred, she managed to avoid being firmly pinned as evil even after the double-fail mission. She seemed comfortable taking calculated risks on team compositions that advanced evil’s win condition.
player_observations.Bob: His playstyle was measured and logic-driven, often grounding discussions with structured reasoning, which fits how Merlin can quietly steer outcomes without overreaching. He managed to guide teams toward some good outcomes early on while avoiding making himself an obvious night-knowledge role.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a persuasive, occasionally bold style that created confusion between them and Merlin, which is very effective for Morgana. They were willing to sit in the spotlight and argue strongly, helping muddy Grace’s reads.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as genuinely puzzled at key moments and seemed to base decisions mostly on mission results and simple logic, which felt very consistent with a straightforward good player. She didn’t over-assert herself, which made her look more trustworthy but also less influential.
player_observations.Frank: Played cautiously and somewhat reactively, often following the louder voices rather than driving the table direction. This made him appear fairly neutral and non-threatening, which is typical of newer or more conservative good players.
player_observations.Grace: Her play was assertive and protective toward players she suspected might be Merlin, which fits Percival’s perspective. She seemed to rely heavily on reading tone and conviction, which made her vulnerable to Morgana’s misdirection.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistent with a generally pro-good voting pattern and tried not to overreact, which helped me avoid looking suspicious, but I didn’t do enough to actively drive the team-building discussions or push hard alternative theories when missions started failing. I need to be more assertive about calling out suspicious patterns (especially the double-fail on Mission 2 and the single-fail on Mission 3) and coordinating with likely trusted players instead of mostly following others’ logic.

player_observations.Alice: She played very subtly evil, blending into reasonable team suggestions while managing to get onto a critical failing mission without drawing too much suspicion. Her ability to look like a reasonable pick for Mission 2 and Mission 4 shows she’s good at hiding in the middle of the pack rather than at the extremes.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he balanced sharing information with staying alive, but his team preferences weren’t forceful or clear enough for the table to reliably follow them. His relatively frequent inclusion on teams and lack of strong resistance to certain lineups made it harder for good to read who he actually distrusted.
player_observations.Charlie: He leaned into a confident, slightly commanding style that fit Morgana well, creating plausible arguments that made him seem informed rather than suspicious. The double-fail on his Mission 2 team suggests he was comfortable taking high-risk, high-reward plays to quickly tilt the game in evil’s favor.
player_observations.Diana: She played like a cautious good player, willing to go on a risky team (Mission 3) but not loudly directing others, which made her seem more neutral than actively cleared. Her inclusion on multiple failing teams made her look ambiguous, and she didn’t push hard to reframe suspicion away from herself with strong counter-arguments.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she came across as somewhat chaotic or hard to read, which unintentionally fit the role and made it difficult for good to confidently classify her. Getting onto the failing Mission 3 and then leading the failing Mission 4 showed she was comfortable making sharp, pivotal moves once she had the opportunity.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she appeared to trust the wrong signals, likely reading Charlie’s confidence as Merlin-like, which steered good away from the right deductions. Her votes and team preferences had influence, and when she leaned the wrong way, it gave evil cover to operate under her apparent endorsement.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Charlie-as-Morgana over Bob-as-Merlin for too long, especially after Mission 2, and didn’t push hard enough to re-center the table on Bob once patterns of double-fails and team comps emerged. I also underutilized my role knowledge as Percival by not more aggressively challenging teams that excluded Bob or leaned heavily on Alice/Charlie after they were repeatedly connected to failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortably took high-risk spots, joining Mission 2 and 4 and still avoiding hard, early suspicion despite being tied to multiple fails, which suggests a calm, low-reactive evil style that relies on others to over-explain for her.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively subtle Merlin, feeding just enough soft resistance to suspicious teams without sounding like he had perfect info, but perhaps so understated that it was easy for evil (and me as Percival) to discount his perspective compared to louder voices.
player_observations.Charlie: Sold the Morgana bluff very convincingly by confidently stepping into the ‘trusted core’ early and accepting heat from the double-fail Mission 2 in a way that felt almost too risky for evil, which made the deception more believable.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a straightforward, mission-focused good player—her inclusion on the failed Mission 3 and 4 teams didn’t come with strong self-defense theatrics, which made her look oddly neutral and therefore easier for evil to keep in mixed teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, blended in surprisingly well despite being disconnected from the other evil roles, joining key failing missions (3) without drawing consistent, targeted suspicion, suggesting a flexible, adaptive style rather than loudly steering the table.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good and low-drama, with a style that doesn’t over-argue reads; that quiet reliability made it harder to distinguish his true alignment but also meant he didn’t strongly shift team-building away from suspicious configurations.
